Jus- tinian's treatment ol it asa civil mode os acquisition is indefensible: it is not gift alone, as Savigny remarks, which confers dominium in any case, but giit in combination with and serving as a iusta causa (p. 200 supr.) ior traditio, exame as sale or exchange might serve. Again, it is not neces· sary that donatio should take the form ol conferring dominium: it may consist in the constitution ola ius in re aliena, the transfer ol possession, the giving ol an actionable promise, or the release ola debt.

Donatio in the widest sense is any other than a testamentary dis· position, which (1) is accompanied by consensus between the two parties: (2) voluntarily, gratuitously, and intentionally improves the proprietary position ol the donee; and (3) actually or prospectively diminishes the property of the donor. Provided these conditions are satisfied, it may take any oi the forms above mentioned.
